Metropolitan Hotel
Nanking, Jan. 29, 1937
Dear Family:
Flew up here from Shanghai this morning for a conference on
International Airmail.
As you know this is the new capital - new since
1927 when the seat of the Government was moved from Pekingâ€¢
This is a modern hotel built and operated by the China Travel
Service which is a tourist bureau with Government complex.
It will be
interesting sometime to come back to Nanking many years from now and
see what has really happened.
China is growing more nationalistic all
the time - the Sian souffle not withstanding
and here especially you
see evidence of the national idea on every side.
The manifestations are
frequently extremely immature and the enthusiasm for the slogan China
the Chinese takes on something of the Collegiate lack of
the dry subtile humor which usually saves John Chinaman from
Rotarian excuses seems to desert him.
case of more national less
rational.
In other words in this respect - there are few others -
Chinese are like the Japs - unable to laugh at themselves.
Nanking is an enormous city in area - it is Los Angeles with
a wall around it - but in an attempt to make people build expensively
up instead of economically out they limit the
amount of ground to be
owned by one citizen to two mow - about one-third of an acre.
result you see a new house here and there with no garden or even yard -
just house.
There is room for thousands upon thousands of such. Ap-
parently they hope to make sprawling Nanking look like congested
Shanghai where
the "foreign devils"
have built a
great city
in a small
At one time they talked of pulling down the
city wall for more
that was just one too many for the most Rotarian of the
Nationalists.
This Hotel used to have a large
sign out in front writ-
ten in English METROPOLITAN HOTEL but the Nationalists had the sign re-
That's funny
too because
tonight at
dinner there was a Russian Jazz band, proverbial Swiss manager,
& tabLe
of Frenchmen,
of Dutchmen and a scattering of
English,
Americans, Japanese
and Chinese.
The only man among those
present known to me was an American Associated Press reporter who was
wearIlg
the perpetual frown of those charged with the responsibility
of telling the world what the Chinese officials themselves do not know,
what they are going to do next.
In front of the hotel runs the long wide new Chung
Shan ROAD
(Central Mountain - Dr.
Sun Yat Sen's posthumous name, edged with patch-
sidewalk in spots but mostly mud.
Along
this road moves
cavalcade of Chinese traffic.
Shrieking wheelbarrows whose axles belie
our New Ingland auxtu axiom
"the wheel
that squeaks the loudest is the
that gets the grease."
donkeys, motor
rickshas and a host of spitting pedestrians all
with that utter and complete disregard of the other fellow which is the
predominate characteristic of the Chinese.
John Chinaman is for him-
self and he doesn't like to
give way to rules of traffic or regulations
which may be all right for the other man but do not apply
to him.
ricksha puller
out in the road well away from the
threading his way
through the wandering pedestrians with crys
and shouts which make no
impression on his noise unmindful compatriots.
You remember Joseph Pulitizer had a sound proof room built to rest his
jaded nerves and nearly went loco when & cat "stamped" around his room.
Well if Joe had been blessed with a yellow epidermis and slant eyes
could have moved his office to a boiler factory and really concen-
trated.
